questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive weakness for the past month. She has noticed increasing difficulty performing household chores and walking her dog. Sometimes, she feels too fatigued to cook dinner. She has noticed that she feels better after sleeping. She does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or a history of recent illness. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She appears fatigued. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 148/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Bilateral expiratory wheezes are heard at both lung bases. Examination shows drooping of the upper eyelids. There is diminished motor strength in the upper extremities. Sensation and reflexes are intact. A treatment that has which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Removal of autoantibodies, immune complexes, and cytotoxic constituents from serum
Competitive blocking of the muscarinic receptor

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In MG, acetylcholine receptor antibodies prevent acetylcholine (ACh) from docking to the ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction. Cholinesterase inhibitors act by inhibiting the enzymatic degradation of ACh, resulting in increased availability of endogenous ACh in the synaptic cleft and improved neuromuscular transmission. Pyridostigmine and neostigmine are the preferred drugs since they only act on peripheral ACh receptors and do not cross the blood-brain barrier, thereby limiting central adverse effects.

Other acetylcholinesterase inhibitors that cross the blood-brain barrier (e.g., physostigmine, rivastigmine) are used in the treatment of glaucoma or atropine overdose.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

B) INCORRECT:

Beta-2 adrenergic agonists (e.g., albuterol, salmeterol, and formoterol) may be used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although this patient's smoking history puts her at increased risk of developing COPD, she lacks other typical symptoms, such as chronic cough with sputum and dyspnea. Beta-2 adrenergic agonists are not effective in MG.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis can be used to treat critically ill patients with autoimmune disorders like Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), lupus erythematosus, and myasthenic crisis. Myasthenic crisis is a severe, life-threatening complication of MG, but this patient does not have any typical symptoms (e.g., respiratory distress, tachycardia, disorientation) that would warrant plasmapheresis. GBS manifests with ascending paralysis (starting in the lower body), paresthesias, and hypo- or areflexia. This patient presents with weakness in the upper body, and her sensation and reflexes are normal, making GBS extremely unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Choline-reactivating oximes, such as pralidoxime, are effective antidotes in organophosphate (insecticide) poisoning. Patients with organophosphate poisoning present with increased salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, bronchospasm, tremor, and paralysis. Oximes are not indicated in the treatment of MG.

E) INCORRECT:

Atropine and atropine-like drugs are useful to treat patients with excess acetylcholine (ACh) due to organophosphate poisoning or cholinesterase inhibitor overdose. Clinical features indicating excess ACh, such as diarrhea, increased secretions, and muscle tremors, are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has ptosis and muscle weakness that is worse in the evenings and improves with rest. These features suggest myasthenia gravis (MG).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of diffuse weakness for the past several months. A lateral x-ray of the chest that was recently obtained as part of a preemployment medical evaluation shows an anterior mediastinal mass. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease. His only medication is rabeprazole. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no splenomegaly. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Fever, night sweats, and weight loss
Elevated TSH and a nodular anterior cervical mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

B symptoms are classically associated with malignancies such as lymphoma, which may manifest with an anterior mediastinal mass usually due to lymph node metastasis. However, the most common cause of an anterior mediastinal mass is thymoma. Furthermore, this patient's generalized muscle weakness suggests a condition that is often associated with thymomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a significant risk factor for many types of bronchogenic carcinoma. Most mediastinal manifestations of bronchogenic carcinoma are due to lymph node metastases, which occur in the middle mediastinum, not the anterior mediastinum, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein is a tumor marker that can be elevated in some types of germ cell tumors – especially in nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. This malignant germ cell tumor typically occurs in younger men (age 20–30 years). Although a germ cell tumor can cause an anterior mediastinal mass, it is not the most likely cause.

D) CORRECT:

Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are used to diagnose myasthenia gravis, a condition that is present in about 30% of patients with thymoma and manifests with fatigable weakness of skeletal muscles. Almost all patients with thymoma and myasthenia gravis are seropositive for these antibodies, which target postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors of normal muscle cells and inhibit signal transduction at the neuromuscular junction. Thymectomy can improve muscle weakness and even cure myasthenia gravis.

Patients with thymoma may be asymptomatic or present with thoracic symptoms (e.g., chest pain, cough, dyspnea, superior vena cava syndrome) or paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., myasthenia gravis).
Image Description:

Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)

A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the pulmonary artery (C).

A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava

E) INCORRECT:

A nodular anterior cervical mass with associated elevated TSH is consistent with goiter. Chronic, untreated goiter can grow into the substernal space, causing an anterior mediastinal mass. However, substernal goiter typically manifests with compressive symptoms (i.e, dysphagia, exertional dyspnea). Another condition is more likely to cause an anterior mediastinal mass and generalized weakness.

F) INCORRECT:

Urinary catecholamines are elevated in some neural tumors such as neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma is rare in adults and would manifest with a posterior mediastinal mass rather than an anterior mediastinal mass.
questions.hint: Thymic lesions, including thymoma, are the most common cause of anterior mediastinal masses, accounting for approx. 50% of cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blurred vision for the past 2 months. During this period, she has also had difficulty chewing and swallowing. She reports that her symptoms worsen throughout the day and improve with rest. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient works as a teacher and has had a great deal of stress lately. She does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine occasionally. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral ptosis and mask-like facies. Muscle strength is decreased in the bilateral lower extremities. The anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibody test is positive. Electromyography shows a decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) testing is indicated to differentiate between different types of hypercortisolism (i.e., primary from secondary). Hypercortisolism typically manifests with central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, abdominal striae, hypertension, hyperglycemia, and proximal muscle weakness. While this patient has proximal muscle weakness, her other findings are not consistent with hypercortisolism. Furthermore, her AChR antibody test is diagnostic of another disease.

B) INCORRECT:

So close! This was a great answer option to consider because acetylcholinesterase (ACh) inhibitors are the pharmacotherapy of choice for MG. However, although physostigmine is in the correct drug class, this specific ACh inhibitor is not used in the treatment of MG because it is able to cross the blood-brain barrier. Pyridostigmine is the preferred agent in MG because it only acts on peripheral ACh receptors, limiting the central adverse effects. Physostigmine is mainly used for the reversal of toxic anticholinergic effects (e.g., in atropine overdose).

Your exam may feature drug names that look or sound similar to the correct pharmacotherapy (e.g., buspirone vs. bupropion) in incorrect answer options, so make sure to read the answer options carefully!

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is used to treat myasthenic crisis. While this patient has MG, she is not in myasthenic crisis, which would manifest with dyspnea, disorientation, agitation, sweating, and tachycardia.

D) CORRECT:

CT scan of the chest is indicated in all patients with newly-diagnosed MG to rule out thymoma. > 75% of MG patients with positive AChR antibodies have thymic abnormalities. The most common abnormality is thymic hyperplasia, but thymic tumors (usually thymoma) are found in 15% of cases. Thymectomy can improve symptoms of myasthenia gravis, even in patients without thymic abnormalities.

Symptomatic treatment of MG consists of cholinesterase inhibitors such as pyridostigmine. Supplemental immunosuppressants (e.g., glucocorticoids, azathioprine) can be added if symptoms persist despite anticholinesterase therapy.
Image Description:

Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)

A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the pulmonary artery (C).

A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) is a confirmatory test for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). Patients with LEMS typically present with proximal muscle weakness, depressed tendon reflexes, and autonomic dysfunction. While this patient presents with muscle weakness, her symptoms worsen throughout the day and with exercise, whereas patients with LEMS show symptom improvement after exercise. Moreover, patients with LEMS would not have a positive AChR antibody test.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

F) INCORRECT:

The Tensilon test is performed in the diagnosis of MG but is rarely used because of its high false-positive rate. This patient has already had her diagnosis of MG confirmed by first-line testing (AChR antibody test), so the Tensilon test would not provide any further information.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigable weakness of the proximal limbs, eye, and bulbar muscles that worsens with activity and improves with rest. These features, together with a positive AChR antibody test, are consistent with myasthenia gravis (MG).

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of difficulty walking for the last 6 months. He reports weakness in his lower legs that improves with exercise and throughout the day. Three months ago, he started adding flax seeds to his breakfast because he is frequently constipated. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 45 years. His current medications include enalapril and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Muscle strength in the lower extremities is decreased. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Active muscle contraction or repeated muscle tapping increases reflex activity. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Demyelinating plaques on a brain MRI
Decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation
Fasciculations and positive sharp waves on EMG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Demyelinating plaques on a brain MRI are seen in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), who may present with bilateral lower limb weakness, gait impairment, and/or autonomic dysfunction. However, motor deficits in MS are due to lesions in the descending motor tracts of the spinal cord and therefore the tendon reflexes are usually exaggerated, not diminished.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with LEMS have autoantibodies against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels at the presynaptic motor neuron. In patients with LEMS, the levels of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction are decreased because the autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal of the motor endplate. This results in reduced neuromuscular transmission and muscle weakness. Repetitive nerve stimulation during exercise or during nerve conduction studies increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which improves muscle strength and the amplitude of muscle action potentials (since the postsynaptic ACh receptors remain intact).

About two-thirds of all cases of LEMS are associated with an underlying malignancy, most commonly small-cell lung cancer. Given this association and the patient's 90-pack year smoking history, it is imperative that he undergoes a chest X-ray and/or CT.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

C) INCORRECT:

Endomysial infiltrate on muscle biopsy is seen in inclusion body myositis (IBM), which typically occurs in men over 50 years of age and manifests with lower limb weakness that increases progressively over the course of years. This patient presents with a 6-month history of waxing-and-waning muscle weakness that improves with exercise. Also, patients with IBM often present with weakness in the hand or fingers. Also, IBM would not account for this patient's symptoms of autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth, constipation) or reduced deep tendon reflexes.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrement in the muscle action potential following repetitive nerve stimulation is seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG may manifest with lower limb weakness, other characteristic features such as ptosis and/or diplopia would also be expected. Also, patients with MG have normal deep tendon reflexes despite limb weakness, and autonomic dysfunction would not occur. This patient has Lambert-Eaton syndrome, in which an incremental response follows repetitive nerve stimulation.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

E) INCORRECT:

Fasciculations and positive sharp waves on EMG would be seen in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS also manifests with weakness and may occasionally be associated with dysautonomia. However, ALS would not account for muscle weakness that improves with exercise or increased reflex activity following active muscle contraction. Additionally, ALS causes progressive rather than episodic weakness.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebral fluid is seen in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), both of which may manifest with progressive bilateral lower limb weakness, difficulty walking, and hyporeflexia. CSF findings may support these diagnoses, but they are not confirmatory (EMG or nerve conduction is required for confirmation). Moreover, while GBS may manifest with symptoms of autonomic dysfunction, this condition usually resolves within 2 months, making GBS unlikely in this patient whose symptoms have been present for the past 6 months. CIDP may persist for months but is not associated with dysautonomia or improvement of weakness following exercise.
questions.hint: This patient presents with weakness of the lower legs that improves throughout the day and with exercise, in addition to autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth, constipation) and reduced reflexes. These features together with a positive smoking history suggest Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of weakness, agitation, and slurred speech. She speaks slowly with frequent breaks and has difficulty keeping her eyes open. Over the past three days, she has had a sore throat, runny nose, and low-grade fever. She says her eyes and tongue have been “heavy” for the past year. She goes to bed early because she feels too tired to talk or watch TV after dinner. She appears pale and anxious. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is bluish discoloration of her lips and around the mouth. Her nostrils dilate with every breath. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is generalized weakness of the proximal muscles. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IV immunoglobulin therapy is a rapid immunomodulating therapy that is used to relieve symptoms mediated by acetylcholine receptor antibodies in cases of myasthenic crisis. This patient would likely benefit from administration of IV immunoglobulin, but at this time, she requires immediate treatment with a different intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyridostigmine, an indirect parasympathomimetic drug, is indicated in long-term symptomatic management of MG. This patient, however, presents with acute symptoms of myasthenic crisis. Her current clinical presentation calls for immediate intervention with a different treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a glucocorticoid immunosuppressant that is used to treat MG refractory to anticholinesterase treatment. Although high-dose prednisone can be used for the acute management of myasthenic crisis, this patient's clinical presentation suggests a life-threatening complication that requires immediate intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is a rapid immunomodulating therapy that is used to remove acetylcholine receptor antibodies from the circulation in cases of myasthenic crisis. Although this patient would likely benefit from plasmapheresis, her current presentation indicates a life-threatening complication of myasthenic crisis that requires a different intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Thymectomy is indicated in all patients with MG and thymoma, and, in the absence of thymoma, it is considered beneficial in patients with MG and acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Although this patient might benefit from surgery in the future, her current presentation is concerning for life-threatening myasthenic crisis, which requires immediate intervention with a different treatment.

F) CORRECT:

Early endotracheal intubation is required in patients with myasthenic crisis and signs of impending respiratory failure (e.g., pallor, anxiety, tachycardia, tachypnea, cyanosis). Myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening complication of MG that commonly occurs within 8–12 months of disease onset. The exacerbation of myasthenic symptoms is commonly triggered by infections (evidenced in this patient by the history of a sore throat, runny nose, and fever), surgery, anesthesia, pregnancy, or certain medications.

Following respiratory stabilization, further treatment consists of plasmapheresis (to remove acetylcholine receptor antibodies from the circulation) and intravenous immunoglobulin. Treatment of MG with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors can be initiated after successful extubation.

G) INCORRECT:

The edrophonium test (or Tensilon test) was formerly used to diagnose MG. Although this patient's clinical history is consistent with MG, a confirmatory test (such as serologic testing for acetylcholine receptor antibodies) is required to establish the diagnosis. Regardless, her current presentation suggests a life-threatening complication of myasthenic crisis that requires immediate intervention.
questions.hint: This patient presents with generalized muscle weakness, agitation, tachycardia, signs of respiratory distress (i.e., tachypnea, cyanosis), and a one-year history of weakness of the eye and bulbar muscles. This constellation of symptoms suggests myasthenia gravis (MG) complicated by acute myasthenic crisis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of weakness for one month. At the end of the day, she feels too fatigued to cook dinner or carry a laundry basket up the stairs. She also complains of double vision after she reads for long periods of time. All of her symptoms improve with rest. Her only medication is pravastatin. Physical examination shows drooping of the upper eyelids. Strength is initially 5/5 in the upper and lower extremities but decreases to 4/5 after a few minutes of sustained resistance. Sensation to light touch is intact and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Type II hypersensitivity reactions are characterized by antibody-mediated cellular destruction, cellular dysfunction, and/or inflammation. In myasthenia gravis, autoantibodies bind to post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in the inhibition of these receptors and impairing the process of neuromuscular transmission. Other examples of similar type II hypersensitivity reactions involving antibody-receptor binding include Graves disease and pemphigus vulgaris.
Image Description:

Blockade of ACh receptors (Left): ACh antibodies bind to postsynaptic ACh receptors and inhibit muscle activation.

Receptor internalization/degradation (middle): Binding of ACh antibody results in accelerated receptor degradation. The receptor is internalized and degraded by the muscle cell.

Complement activation (right): Binding of ACh autoantibodies results in complement activation and membrane attack complex formation, leading to the destruction of the neuromuscular junction and muscle cell lysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, and metachromatic leukodystrophy can cause muscle weakness due to demyelination of peripheral motor nerves. However, Guillain-Barré syndrome typically manifests with acute-onset ascending flaccid paralysis. Symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and metachromatic leukodystrophy typically begin during or before early adulthood, and loss of sensation (especially proprioception) is usually present. Nerve demyelination does not occur in myasthenia gravis.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction occurs in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which can cause diplopia and muscle weakness. However, patients with LEMS typically have diminished deep tendon reflexes and weakness that is worse in the morning, with symptoms usually improving by the end of the day and muscle strength increasing with repeated activity. Botulism is also associated with impaired acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction but patients with botulism have acute-onset, descending flaccid paralysis. Impaired acetylcholine release does not occur in myasthenia gravis.

D) INCORRECT:

Statin-induced myopathy is a known complication of statin therapy that typically manifests as symmetric, proximal muscle weakness (difficulties rising from chairs, raising the arms above the head, or climbing stairs). However, it often manifests with myalgia, which this patient does not have. Moreover, diplopia and improvement of symptoms with rest would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior horn cell destruction occurs in patients with poliomyelitis or motor neuron disease (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy). Poliomyelitis would manifest with acute-onset ascending flaccid paralysis. Muscle weakness due to spinal muscular atrophy begins during or before early adulthood and is associated with decreased deep tendon reflexes. The waxing-and-waning pattern of muscle weakness that is seen in this patient would not occur in either of these conditions.
questions.hint: Diplopia and muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest are highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of lower extremity weakness that improves with exercise. He has difficulty climbing up the stairs to his apartment. He started using a psyllium fiber supplement 2 months ago for constipation. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Muscle strength in the lower extremities is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Repeated muscle tapping increases reflex activity. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Demyelinating periventricular plaques on brain MRI
Decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation
Perimysial inflammation and atrophy on muscle biopsy
Anti-presynaptic calcium channel antibodies in serum
Fasciculations and positive sharp waves on EMG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Demyelinating plaques on brain MRI are seen in patients with multiple sclerosis, which can manifest with bilateral lower limb weakness, gait impairment, and autonomic dysfunction e.g., dry mouth, constipation). However, because motor deficits in multiple sclerosis are due to lesions in the descending motor tracts of the spinal cord, tendon reflexes are usually exaggerated, not diminished.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid is seen in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), both of which can present with progressive bilateral lower limb weakness and hyporeflexia. GBS can manifest with diarrhea/constipation and urinary retention, but it does not usually cause dry mouth. Moreover, symptoms typically resolve within 2 months. CIDP can persist for months, but it is not associated with autonomic dysfunction. Neither GBS nor CIDP is associated with improvement of weakness following exercise or increased reflex activity following repeated muscle contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease in the muscle action potential following repetitive nerve stimulation is seen in patients with myasthenia gravis. Although this condition can manifest with lower limb weakness, the weakness typically worsens with exercise and throughout the day. In addition, patients with myasthenia gravis typically have normal deep tendon reflexes despite limb weakness and do not have autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth, constipation).
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

D) INCORRECT:

Perimysial inflammation and atrophy on muscle biopsy are seen in patients with dermatomyositis, which typically manifests with symmetric, progressively worsening proximal muscle weakness. Dermatomyositis manifests with characteristic skin findings (e.g., Gottron papules, heliotrope rash, shawl sign), which this patient does not have. Moreover, this condition does not cause autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation) or decreased deep tendon reflexes.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) have autoantibodies against P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels at the myoneural junction that impair the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal of the motor end plate. Repetitive nerve stimulation during exercise or during nerve conduction studies increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which improves muscle strength and the amplitude of muscle action potentials (since the postsynaptic ACh receptors remain intact). Patients with LEMS can develop autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation, erectile dysfunction) and cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., diplopia, ptosis, dysphagia). About two-thirds of all cases of LEMS are associated with an underlying malignancy, most commonly small cell lung cancer. Given this association and the patient's 90 pack-year smoking history, it is imperative that he undergo a chest x-ray and/or CT scan.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

F) INCORRECT:

Fasciculations and positive sharp waves on EMG are seen in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which can manifest with weakness and is occasionally associated with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation). However, ALS is not associated with improvement of weakness following exercise or increased reflex activity following repeated muscle contraction. In addition, ALS causes progressive, rather than episodic, weakness.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with lower extremity muscle weakness that improves with exercise, in addition to autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation) and decreased reflexes. Together with a positive smoking history, these features suggest a diagnosis of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

questions.text: A previously healthy 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7-month history of diffuse weakness. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. A lateral x-ray of the chest shows an anterior mediastinal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: History of fever, night sweats, and weight loss
Elevated TSH and a nodular anterior cervical mass

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acetylcholine receptor antibody detection is used to diagnose myasthenia gravis, which is present in about 30% of patients with thymoma and may present with diffuse weakness. Thymic lesions, including thymoma, are the most common underlying cause of anterior mediastinal masses, accounting for ∼ 50% of cases. The peak incidence of thymomas is between 40–60 years of age. Patients with thymoma may be asymptomatic, or they may present with chest pain, dyspnea, and cough.

B) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC), which typically develops in smokers, can cause proximal muscle weakness (Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome). However, the mediastinal manifestations of SCLC are typically due to hilar lymphadenopathy, which occurs in the middle mediastinum, not the anterior mediastinum, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein is a tumor marker that can be elevated in some germ cell tumors, especially nonseminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCT). NSGCT typically occurs in young men (20–30 years of age) and is, therefore, less likely in this patient. Although germ cell tumors can cause anterior mediastinal masses, they are not the most likely cause.

D) INCORRECT:

B symptoms are classically associated with lymphoma. Although lymphoma can cause an anterior mediastinal mass due to anterior mediastinal lymphadenopathy, it is not the most common cause.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary catecholamines are elevated in some neural tumors such as neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma is rare in adults and would present as a posterior mediastinal mass rather than an anterior mediastinal mass.

F) INCORRECT:

A nodular anterior cervical mass in association with elevated TSH is consistent with goiter. Chronic, untreated goiter can grow into the substernal space, causing an anterior mediastinal mass. However, goiter is not the most likely cause of an anterior mediastinal mass. In addition, substernal goiter typically causes compressive symptoms (e.g., dysphagia), which are not present in this patient.
questions.hint: Thymoma is the most common type of anterior mediastinal mass.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for blurry vision and increased difficulty walking over the past month. He feels very fatigued after watering his garden but feels better after taking a nap. He has not had any recent illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows drooping of the upper eyelids bilaterally and diminished motor strength in the upper extremities. Sensation to light touch and deep tendon reflexes are intact. An x-ray of the chest shows low lung volumes bilaterally. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Muscarinic ACh receptor antagonists (e.g., atropine) can be used to treat patients with excess ACh due to organophosphate poisoning or cholinesterase inhibitor overdose. However, clinical features indicating excess ACh, such as diarrhea, increased secretions, and muscle tremors, are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Choline-reactivating oximes, such as pralidoxime, are effective antidotes in organophosphate (insecticide) poisoning. Patients with organophosphate poisoning present with increased salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, bronchospasm, tremor, and paralysis, which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

D2 receptors agonists (e.g., bromocriptine and pramipexole) can be used to treat Parkinson disease but are not used in the management of MG. While Parkinson disease manifests with weakness, it also presents with other symptoms such as tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, masked face, not the bilateral eyelid droop and decreased lung volumes seen in this patient.

D2 receptor agonists can also be used to treat restless leg syndrome and prolactinomas.

D) INCORRECT:

β2 adrenergic receptor agonists (e.g., albuterol, salmeterol, and formoterol) may be used to treat COPD. Although this patient's smoking history puts him at increased risk of developing COPD, he lacks all of the typical symptoms, such as chronic cough with sputum and dyspnea. β2 adrenergic agonists are not effective in myasthenia gravis (MG).

E) CORRECT:

Cholinesterase inhibitors are used to manage the symptoms of myasthenia gravis (MG) because they increase the availability of endogenous acetylcholine (ACh) in the neuromuscular junction, which competes with the ACh receptor antibodies that would otherwise block ACh receptors. Pyridostigmine or alternatively neostigmine are the preferred drugs, since they only act on peripheral ACh receptors and do not cross the blood-brain barrier, which limits their adverse effects.

Some cholinesterase inhibitors can also cross the blood-brain barrier (e.g., physostigmine) and can be used to treat glaucoma or atropine overdose.
questions.hint: This patient has ptosis as well as weakness that is worse with activity and improves with rest. These clinical features suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis (MG).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and weakness when trying to brush her hair. She reports that these symptoms are worse after she exercises and disappear after she rests for a few hours. Physical examination shows drooping of her right upper eyelid that worsens when the patient is asked to gaze at the ceiling for 2 minutes. There is diminished motor strength in the upper extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with diplopia, worsening proximal muscle weakness on exertion, and ptosis. While skeletal muscle is affected, deep tendon reflexes and the pupillary reflex are normal. In MG, autoantibodies against the post-synaptic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors compete competitively with ACh in the synaptic cleft. After a period of rest, the ACh levels build up, allowing for stimulation of the motor end plate. As a result, symptoms worsen with exercise or constant use and improve with rest. The diagnosis of MG is based on these clinical findings, detection of antibodies (acetylcholine receptor antibodies in 90% of patients), and electrodiagnostic tests (such as repetitive nerve stimulation).

CT of the chest should be obtained in patients with MG to screen for thymoma.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

While Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) also manifests with muscle weakness, symptoms are worst in the morning and improve throughout the day and with repeated activity. In patients with LEMS, levels of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction are decreased because the autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal of the motor end plate. Repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which improves muscle strength. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of LEMS such as autonomic symptoms (e.g., dry mouth and constipation).
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

C) INCORRECT:

The hallmark of polymyositis is slowly progressive, symmetric proximal muscle weakness that affects the axial musculature (e.g., the deltoids and the hip flexors), with upper extremity involvement being more prominent. However, ocular muscles are almost never affected and the weakness would not improve with rest.

D) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically presents in older individuals (50–70 years of age) with progressively worsening features of both upper motor neuron degeneration (hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron degeneration (hyporeflexia, decreased muscle tone, atrophy). Improvement of motor symptoms with rest would not be seen.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) usually occurs 1–4 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection and is characterized by symmetric flaccid paralysis. Although this patient does have motor weakness, she has no history of recent infection and paralysis in GBS is typically ascending, progressive, and does not improve with rest. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of GBS such as symmetric paresthesias in the hands and feet.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can present with muscle weakness and gait impairment; the presentation can be highly variable and depends on the precise location of the lesion in the central nervous system. Ocular symptoms may also arise in the setting of optic neuritis, which is commonly seen in MS. The timing of this patient's deterioration and improvement in muscle function is crucial, as the characteristic course of MS involves intermittent waxing and waning of symptoms over weeks to months. This patient's symptoms, however, improve with a few hours of rest, making MS unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by autoimmune-mediated destruction of postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AchR), which results in impaired neurotransmission and diminished skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica manifests with proximal myopathy, but its main symptoms are myalgia and muscle stiffness rather than weakness. Systemic symptoms, such as weight loss, may be seen in polymyalgia rheumatica, but autonomic dysfunction and hyporeflexia would not be expected. Polymyalgia rheumatica is not associated with lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

F) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of upper extremity weakness and fatigue for the past 4 months. She has had difficulty combing her hair and lifting objects. She has also had difficulty rising from her bed in the mornings for 2 months. Over the past month, she started using over-the-counter mouth rinses for dry mouth. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows decreased deep tendon reflexes. Repetitive muscle tapping shows increased reflex activity. There are no fasciculations or muscle atrophy. A low-dose CT scan of the chest shows a 3-cm mass with heterogeneous calcifications in the center of the right lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CNS is one of the most common locations for lung cancer metastasis, which can present with focal neurological deficits. Patients with brain metastasis may exhibit muscle weakness, as seen here. However, upper motor neuron symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) would also be expected, rather than the decreased deep tendon reflexes observed in this patient. In addition, brain metastasis commonly presents with headaches, cognitive deficits, and seizures, none of which are present here. Moreover, her autonomic symptom (dry mouth) and the increased reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory myopathies (IM), such as polymyositis and dermatomyositis, typically manifest with proximal muscle weakness, as seen in this patient. However, her autonomic symptom (dry mouth) and the decreased deep tendon reflexes with improvement after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with IM. Although a strong association exists between dermatomyositis and malignancy, this patient lacks the typical cutaneous manifestations of this disease (i.e., Gottron papules, heliotrope rash), which excludes dermatomyositis as the underlying mechanism responsible for her presentation.

C) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic autoimmune disease, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. In LEMS, antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels impair acetylcholine (ACh) release in the neuromuscular junction. This leads to proximal muscle weakness, autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation), and decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. A unique feature of LEMS is an improvement in strength and reflex activity with repeated use/stimulation. Since postsynaptic ACh receptors remain intact in LEMS, once enough ACh has built up in the postsynaptic cleft from repeated stimulation, muscle contraction can return.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

D) INCORRECT:

Hereditary causes of muscle weakness include muscular dystrophies (e.g., Duchenne muscular dystrophy), hereditary motor sensory neuropathies (HMSN) (e.g., Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease), and congenital myopathies. Although decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen here, may be found in all of these conditions, increased reflex activity after repeated stimulation would not be present. Moreover, further symptoms such as muscle atrophy and, in the case of HMSN, sensory deficits would be expected. Finally, these hereditary conditions almost exclusively manifest in childhood or early adulthood.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasion of a lung carcinoma into the cervical sympathetic chain can lead to Pancoast syndrome, presenting with upper extremity weakness and loss of deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. However, muscle weakness in Pancoast syndrome is typically unilateral. In addition, further symptoms caused by the compression or infiltration of local structures by the tumor would be expected (e.g., shoulder pain, muscle atrophy, sensory deficits, Horner syndrome, hoarseness, and superior vena cava syndrome). An increase in reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation is inconsistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, the patient's CT revealed a mass in the center of the right lung, whereas Pancoast tumors are always located in the superior sulcus.

F) INCORRECT:

Some viral infections that affect the anterior horn cells can cause muscle weakness, resulting in flaccid paralysis or invasion of the muscle itself (i.e., myositis). Viruses that cause flaccid paralysis include poliovirus, nonpolio enteroviruses, and West Nile virus, all of which are extremely unlikely in a patient without a travel history to endemic areas. Moreover, further symptoms such as muscle fasciculations, atrophy, and signs of infection (e.g., fever, malaise, headache) would be expected. Viral myositis is commonly caused by influenza viruses and enteroviruses; patients typically present with fever, myalgia, and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, none of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, her slowly progressive symptoms, autonomic symptom (dry mouth), and the increased reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with an infectious cause.
questions.hint: A CT scan showing a 3-cm pulmonary mass with irregular calcifications in a patient with a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking is suspicious for lung malignancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive weakness. During this time, she has had increasing difficulty climbing the stairs to her 5th-floor apartment, worsening double vision, and fatigue. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She works as a teacher and finds it increasingly difficult to pursue her occupation because of her symptoms. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 62/min, and blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg. Examination of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is 3/5 on abduction of the shoulders and flexion of the hips, and 4/5 in the remaining muscle groups of all extremities. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ and symmetric. On cranial nerve examination, there is drooping of the upper eyelids and she reports double vision when moving her eyes. Placement of an ice pack on her eyelids for 2 minutes improves the eyelid drooping. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration is 4.2 μU/mL. Results of other screening laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) typically affects older men (40–70 years of age) and younger women (20–40 years of age) and is characterized by ptosis, diplopia, and proximal limb weakness. A positive ice pack test supports the diagnosis of MG. The presence of acetylcholine receptor antibodies in the serum and electromyography showing a decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation confirms the diagnosis. Treatment with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., pyridostigmine) is the standard approach in MG. Supplemental immunosuppression with glucocorticoids is added if symptoms persist despite treatment with pyridostigmine.

MG is also associated with other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto thyroiditis, which this patient may have (indicated by increased TSH).
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyositis (PM) typically affects women aged 30 to 60 years and manifests with symmetric progressive proximal muscle weakness, which often leads to difficulties climbing stairs. However, other features of PM, such as dysphagia, muscle tenderness, and Raynaud phenomenon, are not seen in this patient. Moreover, ocular symptoms (e.g., diplopia, ptosis) are typically not seen in PM.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) can manifest with bilateral ptosis, diplopia, and proximal muscle weakness. However, CPEO is a type of mitochondrial myopathy that affects multiple family members, and this patient has no family history of serious illness. Moreover, a positive ice pack test is not expected in patients with CPEO.

D) INCORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is associated with small cell lung carcinoma and can manifest with proximal limb weakness and less commonly with ocular symptoms (e.g., diplopia, ptosis). However, in patients with LEMS, reflexes are typically reduced or absent and muscle strength improves with exercise. Moreover, LEMS is also associated with symptoms of autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation).
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

E) INCORRECT:

Graves disease typically affects women aged 20 to 40 years and can manifest with ocular symptoms (e.g., diplopia), which is seen here. However, this patient lacks typical features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., heat intolerance, weight loss, tachycardia), and decreased TSH would be expected in affected individuals, whereas this patient has increased TSH. In addition, proximal muscle weakness and ptosis are not typically seen in Graves disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) typically manifests in individuals between 20-40 years of age and is more common in women than in men. Common symptoms of MS include fatigue, muscle weakness, and diplopia. However, the motor deficits seen in MS are due to spinal cord lesions in the pyramidal tracts that lead to hyperreflexia, whereas this patient has normal reflexes. Moreover, a positive ice pack test is not expected in patients with MS.

G) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) can manifest with progressive muscle weakness. However, ALS most commonly affects individuals aged 50 to 70 years that present with both upper and lower motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity, muscle atrophy, fasciculations) and/or bulbar symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia). Moreover, a positive ice pack test is not expected in patients with ALS.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.
questions.hint: A chest CT should be performed in this patient to rule out thymoma.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes, myasthenia gravis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with drooping of the eyelids, increasing difficulty swallowing and speaking, and difficulty climbing stairs. She reports some difficulty breathing during the past 24 hours. Her current medications include pyridostigmine, insulin glargine, insulin lispro, and levothyroxine.
On examination, she has a nasal voice but can protect her airway and manage her secretions effectively. She has bilateral ptosis that is worse on the right and an apparent right abduction deficit with rightward gaze. Her arm abductors and hip flexors can work against gravity but not resistance, and both fatigue easily.
A bedside FVC is low at 1.1 liters.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis affects neuromuscular junction transmission. It can cause a range of neurologic symptoms, from extraocular muscle weakness alone to severe diaphragmatic weakness and respiratory failure. Most patients with myasthenia gravis, however, live fully functional lives when treated appropriately.

Patients with mild exacerbations of myasthenia gravis generally respond well to pyridostigmine. However, in more-severe exacerbations, pyridostigmine alone is unlikely to provide adequate benefit.

For more-severe exacerbations, as well as for myasthenic crisis (defined as weakness from acquired myasthenia gravis that is life-threatening and severe enough to necessitate intubation or to delay extubation following surgery), the main treatment options are intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) administration or plasmapheresis. IVIG usually improves symptoms within days and has been the standard treatment, but plasmapheresis is equally effective and is sometimes preferred because of its faster therapeutic effect.

Key learning point: Treatment of a moderate-to-severe exacerbation of myasthenia gravis consists of either intravenous immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis.

B) INCORRECT:

Atropine has anticholinergic effects against the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors with limited effect on the nicotinic receptors. This medication is not indicated for patients with symptomatic myasthenia gravis, because it can further exacerbate the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Benztropine has an anticholinergic effect against both the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. This medication is not indicated for patients with symptomatic myasthenia gravis, because it can further exacerbate the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Ipratropium bromide has anticholinergic effects against the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors with limited effect on the nicotinic receptors. This medication is not indicated for patients with symptomatic myasthenia gravis, because it can further exacerbate the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-dose glucocorticoids can improve mild myasthenic symptoms in the short term, but high-dose glucocorticoids, such as intravenous methylprednisolone, would not be beneficial in someone with severe symptoms (myasthenic crisis) and may, in fact, worsen myasthenic symptoms.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports a one-week history of shortness of breath on exertion and difficulty swallowing. Both symptoms are worse in the evening.
Vital signs, pulse oximetry findings, and a cardiopulmonary examination are normal. The cranial-nerve examination is notable for left-eye ptosis, limited right-eye abduction with right lateral gaze, and mildly dysarthric speech. The patient uses her arms to get out of the chair. Reflexes and sensation are intact.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polymyositis is very unlikely in this patient, as it does not cause ptosis or ophthalmoplegia.

B) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis is frequently characterized by ptosis and ophthalmoplegia — and often generalized weakness, such as proximal-limb weakness. The weakness usually involves fatigability, which is the tendency for weakness to worsen with repetitive movement. Dyspnea and other bulbar symptoms, such as dysphagia and dysarthria, can also occur.

The diagnosis of myasthenia gravis can be established with the use of a serum acetylcholine-receptor antibody test, although this test is negative in up to 20% of patients with the disease. Some seronegative patients will have antibodies to other neuromuscular junction proteins, such as muscle-specific kinase, but 10% to 15% of patients will have no serum antibodies. In patients with typical features of myasthenia gravis and a negative antibody test, electromyography with repetitive nerve stimulation should be performed to help establish the diagnosis.

Key learning point: The combination of dyspnea, dysphagia, ptosis, and ophthalmoplegia in a young woman is most consistent with a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

C) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is very unlikely in this patient, as it does not cause ptosis or ophthalmoplegia.

D) INCORRECT:

A brainstem stroke should be considered in patients with vascular risk factors but is unlikely in an otherwise healthy young woman.

E) INCORRECT:

Ptosis and ophthalmoplegia are uncommon in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which is a rare, often paraneoplastic syndrome that predominantly causes leg weakness in patients older than age 40. Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome is often more slowly progressive, as opposed to the fluctuating weakness of myasthenia gravis. Sometimes these conditions manifest similarly, in which case serum antibody testing and electromyography can be useful in distinguishing between the two conditions.
