As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) usually occurs 1–4 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection and is characterized by symmetric flaccid paralysis. Although this patient does have motor weakness, she has no history of recent infection and paralysis in GBS is typically ascending, progressive, and does not improve with rest. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of GBS such as symmetric paresthesias in the hands and feet.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can present with muscle weakness and gait impairment; the presentation can be highly variable and depends on the precise location of the lesion in the central nervous system. Ocular symptoms may also arise in the setting of optic neuritis, which is commonly seen in MS. The timing of this patient's deterioration and improvement in muscle function is crucial, as the characteristic course of MS involves intermittent waxing and waning of symptoms over weeks to months. This patient's symptoms, however, improve with a few hours of rest, making MS unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by autoimmune-mediated destruction of postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AchR), which results in impaired neurotransmission and diminished skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes, myasthenia gravis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with drooping of the eyelids, increasing difficulty swallowing, and some difficulty breathing during the past 24 hours. Her current medications include pyridostigmine, insulin glargine, insulin lispro, and levothyroxine. On examination, she has a nasal voice but can protect her airway and manage her secretions effectively. Further examination reveals diplopia and decreased muscle strength bilaterally in the lower extremities. Bedside lung function testing reveals a low forced vital capacity. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis can cause a range of neurologic symptoms, from extraocular muscle weakness alone to severe diaphragmatic weakness and respiratory failure. Most patients with myasthenia gravis, however, live fully functional lives when treated appropriately.

Patients with mild exacerbations of myasthenia gravis generally respond well to pyridostigmine. However, in more-severe exacerbations, pyridostigmine alone is unlikely to provide adequate benefit.

For more-severe exacerbations, as well as for myasthenic crisis (defined as weakness from acquired myasthenia gravis that is life-threatening and severe enough to necessitate intubation or to delay extubation following surgery), the main treatment options are intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) administration or plasmapheresis. IVIG usually improves symptoms within days and has been the standard treatment, but plasmapheresis is equally effective and is sometimes preferred because of its faster therapeutic effect.

Key learning point: Treatment of a moderate-to-severe exacerbation of myasthenia gravis consists of either intravenous immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis.

B) INCORRECT:

Atropine has anticholinergic effects against the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors with limited effect on the nicotinic receptors. This medication is not indicated for patients with symptomatic myasthenia gravis, because it can further exacerbate the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Benztropine has an anticholinergic effect against both the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. This medication is not indicated for patients with symptomatic myasthenia gravis, because it can further exacerbate the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Ipratropium bromide has anticholinergic effects against the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors with limited effect on the nicotinic receptors. This medication is not indicated for patients with symptomatic myasthenia gravis, because it can further exacerbate the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-dose glucocorticoids can improve mild myasthenic symptoms in the short term, but high-dose glucocorticoids, such as intravenous methylprednisolone, would not be beneficial in someone with severe symptoms (myasthenic crisis) and may, in fact, worsen myasthenic symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's ptosis, muscle fatiguability, and bulbar muscle weakness suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive weakness for the past month. She has noticed fatigue and increasing difficulty performing household chores in the evenings. She has noticed that she feels better after sleeping. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows drooping of the upper eyelids. There is diminished motor strength in the upper extremities. Sensation and reflexes are intact. A treatment that has which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Removal of autoantibodies and immune complexes from serum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In MG, acetylcholine receptor antibodies prevent acetylcholine (ACh) from docking to the ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction. Cholinesterase inhibitors act by inhibiting the enzymatic degradation of ACh, resulting in increased availability of endogenous ACh in the synaptic cleft and improved neuromuscular transmission. Pyridostigmine and neostigmine are the preferred drugs since they only act on peripheral ACh receptors and do not cross the blood-brain barrier, thereby limiting central adverse effects.

Other acetylcholinesterase inhibitors that cross the blood-brain barrier (e.g., physostigmine, rivastigmine) are used in the treatment of glaucoma or atropine overdose.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

B) INCORRECT:

Beta-2 adrenergic agonists (e.g., albuterol, salmeterol, and formoterol) may be used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although this patient's smoking history puts her at increased risk of developing COPD, she lacks other typical symptoms, such as chronic cough with sputum and dyspnea. Beta-2 adrenergic agonists are not effective in MG.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis can be used to treat critically ill patients with autoimmune disorders like Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), lupus erythematosus, and myasthenic crisis. Myasthenic crisis is a severe, life-threatening complication of MG, but this patient does not have any typical symptoms (e.g., respiratory distress, tachycardia, disorientation) that would warrant plasmapheresis. GBS manifests with ascending paralysis (starting in the lower body), paresthesias, and hypo- or areflexia. This patient presents with weakness in the upper body, and her sensation and reflexes are normal, making GBS extremely unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Choline-reactivating oximes, such as pralidoxime, are effective antidotes in organophosphate (insecticide) poisoning. Patients with organophosphate poisoning present with increased salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, bronchospasm, tremor, and paralysis. Oximes are not indicated in the treatment of MG.

E) INCORRECT:

Atropine and atropine-like drugs are useful to treat patients with excess acetylcholine (ACh) due to organophosphate poisoning or cholinesterase inhibitor overdose. Clinical features indicating excess ACh, such as diarrhea, increased secretions, and muscle tremors, are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has ptosis and muscle weakness that is worse in the evenings and improves with rest. These features suggest myasthenia gravis (MG).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of blurred vision for the past 2 months. During this period, she has also had difficulty chewing and swallowing. She reports that her symptoms worsen throughout the day and improve with rest. Physical examination shows bilateral ptosis and mask-like facies. The anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibody test is positive. Electromyography shows a decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) testing is indicated to differentiate between different types of hypercortisolism (i.e., primary from secondary). Hypercortisolism typically manifests with central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, abdominal striae, hypertension, hyperglycemia, and proximal muscle weakness. While this patient has proximal muscle weakness, her other findings are not consistent with hypercortisolism. Furthermore, her AChR antibody test is diagnostic of another disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is used to treat myasthenic crisis. While this patient has MG, she is not in myasthenic crisis, which would manifest with dyspnea, disorientation, agitation, sweating, and tachycardia.

C) CORRECT:

CT scan of the chest is indicated in all patients with newly-diagnosed MG to rule out thymoma. > 75% of MG patients with positive AChR antibodies have thymic abnormalities. The most common abnormality is thymic hyperplasia, but thymic tumors (usually thymoma) are found in 15% of cases. Thymectomy can improve symptoms of myasthenia gravis, even in patients without thymic abnormalities.

Symptomatic treatment of MG consists of cholinesterase inhibitors such as pyridostigmine. Supplemental immunosuppressants (e.g., glucocorticoids, azathioprine) can be added if symptoms persist despite anticholinesterase therapy.
Image Description:

Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)

A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the pulmonary artery (C).

A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) is a confirmatory test for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). Patients with LEMS typically present with proximal muscle weakness, depressed tendon reflexes, and autonomic dysfunction. While this patient presents with muscle weakness, her symptoms worsen throughout the day and with exercise, whereas patients with LEMS show symptom improvement after exercise. Moreover, patients with LEMS would not have a positive AChR antibody test.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

E) INCORRECT:

The Tensilon test is performed in the diagnosis of MG but is rarely used because of its high false-positive rate. This patient has already had her diagnosis of MG confirmed by first-line testing (AChR antibody test), so the Tensilon test would not provide any further information.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigable weakness of the eye and bulbar muscles that worsens with activity and improves with rest. These features, together with a positive AChR antibody test, are consistent with myasthenia gravis (MG).

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

E) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty keeping her eyelids elevated for the past 3 months. She experiences intermittent double vision, which worsens late in the day, and generalized weakness after prolonged activity that improves with brief rest. Deep tendon reflexes are normal, and there are no sensory deficits. Muscle bulk is normal without atrophy. Cranial nerve examination is otherwise unremarkable. An edrophonium test increases her muscle strength, and serum anti–acetylcholine receptor antibodies are present. A CT scan of the chest shows no thymoma. She has not previously received treatment for her condition (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Anti–acetylcholine receptor antibodies
Positive
Negative


CT scan of the chest: No thymoma
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness due to autoantibodies targeting nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. Pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, increases acetylcholine availability, enhancing neuromuscular transmission. It is effective in alleviating symptoms, particularly in patients with mild to moderate disease without thymoma. The presence of anti–acetylcholine receptor antibodies and positive edrophonium test support the diagnosis, making pyridostigmine the appropriate initial therapy.

Key learning point: Pyridostigmine is the first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis, as it is a long-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that improves neuromuscular transmission and muscle strength.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasma exchange is used for severe exacerbations or crises with respiratory compromise. This patient has stable symptoms without acute respiratory failure, making plasma exchange inappropriate as initial therapy. Initial management typically involves symptomatic treatment and long-term strategies.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous glucocorticoids are used in myasthenic crisis or severe cases requiring rapid immunosuppression. This patient has mild symptoms without respiratory compromise. High-dose steroids can cause transient worsening of symptoms and are not typically first-line in stable patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Thymectomy is considered in myasthenia gravis with thymoma or refractory disease. This patient has no thymoma and has not yet received medical treatment. Thymectomy is not indicated as initial therapy in the absence of thymic pathology or treatment failure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and weakness when brushing her hair. She reports that her symptoms worsen after exercise and improve after a few hours of rest. On examination, she has right upper eyelid drooping that becomes more pronounced when she is asked to gaze at the ceiling for 2 minutes. There is decreased motor strength in the upper extremities. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically presents in older individuals (50–70 years of age) with progressively worsening features of both upper motor neuron degeneration (hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron degeneration (hyporeflexia, decreased muscle tone, atrophy). Improvement of motor symptoms with rest would not be seen.

B) CORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with diplopia, worsening proximal muscle weakness on exertion, and ptosis. While skeletal muscle is affected, deep tendon reflexes and the pupillary reflex are normal. In MG, autoantibodies against the post-synaptic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors compete competitively with ACh in the synaptic cleft. After a period of rest, the ACh levels build up, allowing for stimulation of the motor end plate. As a result, symptoms worsen with exercise or constant use and improve with rest. The diagnosis of MG is based on these clinical findings, detection of antibodies (acetylcholine receptor antibodies in 90% of patients), and electrodiagnostic tests (such as repetitive nerve stimulation).

CT of the chest should be obtained in patients with MG to screen for thymoma.

Key learning point: Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest due to autoantibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

While Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) also manifests with muscle weakness, symptoms are worst in the morning and improve throughout the day and with repeated activity. In patients with LEMS, levels of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction are decreased because the autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal of the motor end plate. Repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which improves muscle strength. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of LEMS such as autonomic symptoms (e.g., dry mouth and constipation).

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) usually occurs 1–4 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection and is characterized by symmetric flaccid paralysis. Although this patient does have motor weakness, she has no history of recent infection and paralysis in GBS is typically ascending, progressive, and does not improve with rest. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of GBS such as symmetric paresthesias in the hands and feet.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can present with muscle weakness and gait impairment; the presentation can be highly variable and depends on the precise location of the lesion in the central nervous system. Ocular symptoms may also arise in the setting of optic neuritis, which is commonly seen in MS. The timing of this patient's deterioration and improvement in muscle function is crucial, as the characteristic course of MS involves intermittent waxing and waning of symptoms over weeks to months. This patient's symptoms, however, improve with a few hours of rest, making MS unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by autoimmune-mediated destruction of postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AchR), which results in impaired neurotransmission and diminished skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He reports that climbing the stairs becomes easier after he has exercised. He has also experienced a 4.6-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, he has dry mucous membranes. His pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremities is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

B) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.

Key learning point: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is a paraneoplastic disorder, often linked to small-cell lung cancer, characterized by proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity, autonomic symptoms, and reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 6-month history of intermittent diplopia presents with worsening dysphagia and voice changes over the past 2 days. She recently completed a course of ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection. Physical examination shows bilateral ptosis that worsens with sustained upward gaze, nasal speech, and difficulty swallowing liquids. Maximal inspiratory pressure is -60 cmH2O. What clinical finding would be most concerning for disease progression requiring immediate intervention?

choices.text: A maximal inspiratory pressure less negative than -30 cmH2O

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal deep tendon reflexes are expected in myasthenia gravis and do not suggest disease progression. This is a consistent finding throughout the disease course and helps differentiate myasthenia gravis from other neuromuscular disorders.

B) INCORRECT:

Improvement with rest is a classic feature of myasthenia gravis, regardless of disease severity, and is expected rather than concerning.

C) INCORRECT:

While muscle weakness can be symmetric in myasthenia gravis, this finding alone does not indicate disease progression requiring immediate intervention. The pattern of weakness is less important than the severity and respiratory involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Deep tendon reflexes remain normal in myasthenia gravis regardless of disease severity. Hyperreflexia suggests upper motor neuron pathology rather than neuromuscular junction disease and is not a feature of myasthenic crisis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient likely has myasthenia gravis based on the characteristic pattern of fatigable weakness affecting ocular muscles (bilateral ptosis that worsens with sustained upward gaze), bulbar muscles (dysphagia, voice changes, nasal speech), and recent fluoroquinolone exposure, which is a known exacerbating factor. A maximal inspiratory pressure less negative than -30 cmH2O or a vital capacity below 15 mL/kg indicates impending respiratory failure in myasthenia gravis and is a criterion for intubation and mechanical ventilation. This represents progression to myasthenic crisis, which is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate intervention with respiratory support and either plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis treated with pyridostigmine presents with progressive weakness over 48 hours after starting ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection. She reports new difficulty swallowing and voice changes. Her husband notes she has been sleeping more upright due to breathing difficulties. On examination, she appears anxious with weak voice, bilateral ptosis, poor gag reflex, and difficulty lifting her head. Vital signs are BP, 142/88 mm Hg; P, 110; R, 28; and oxygen saturation, 93% on room air. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.36, PCO2 49 mm Hg, PO2 65 mm Hg. Pulmonary function testing shows vital capacity of 12 mL/kg and maximal inspiratory pressure of -25 cm H2O. Ciprofloxacin is discontinued. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is appropriate immunomodulatory therapy for myasthenic crisis, but another urgent intervention is required for this patient first.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose prednisone is part of appropriate immunomodulatory therapy for myasthenic crisis, but another urgent intervention is required for this patient first.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient is in myasthenic crisis with impending respiratory failure based on vital capacity less than 15 mL/kg and maximal inspiratory pressure less negative than -30 cm H2O. Her weakness, dysphonia, and dyspnea are additional high-risk indicators of impending respiratory failure. Approximately 60–90% of patients with myasthenic crises require intubation with mechanical ventilation. Elective intubation is preferred over emergent intubation. Immunomodulatory therapy with high-dose prednisone plus intravenous immunoglobulin or plasma exchange is the standard treatment for myasthenic crisis, however, respiratory stabilization should be addressed first.

D) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation is contraindicated in this patient due to her severe bulbar dysfunction and inability to protect the airway.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing pyridostigmine alone is insufficient for myasthenic crisis. Pyridostigmine dosing may be titrated as needed to improve myasthenic weakness in clinically stable patients. However, this patient requires other management interventions because she is experiencing an acute, life-threatening exacerbation of myasthenic symptoms with impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of intermittent double vision and eyelid drooping. She notes her symptoms are minimal in the morning but worsen significantly by the end of her workday as a graphic designer. She also reports occasional difficulty chewing her food during dinner. On examination, she has bilateral ptosis and disconjugate gaze. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Improvement in muscle strength with repetitive use
Worsening of ptosis after 60 seconds of sustained upward gaze
Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye on lateral gaze
Fixed, dilated pupils with symmetric facial weakness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This finding, known as facilitation, is characteristic of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). In LEMS, autoantibodies target presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels, impairing acetylcholine release. Repetitive nerve stimulation allows intracellular calcium to accumulate, which facilitates acetylcholine release and transiently improves strength. This is the opposite of this patient's history of worsening weakness with activity.

B) CORRECT:

This finding demonstrates fatigability, the hallmark of myasthenia gravis. The underlying pathophysiology involves autoantibodies that block or destroy postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. With sustained muscle contraction, the amount of acetylcholine released from the presynaptic terminal diminishes. In a healthy individual, there are enough receptors to compensate, but in myasthenia gravis, the reduced number of available receptors leads to a failure of neuromuscular transmission and clinically apparent weakness. This provocative test directly elicits this phenomenon.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), a gaze palsy caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the brainstem. While INO causes diplopia, it is a disorder of gaze coordination rather than primary muscle weakness. This patient's symptoms of fatigability, ptosis, and difficulty chewing are not features of INO.

D) INCORRECT:

These findings, along with ptosis, constitute Horner syndrome, which results from disruption of the sympathetic nerve supply. While this patient has ptosis, it is due to weakness of the skeletal levator palpebrae superioris muscle. The ptosis in Horner syndrome is typically milder and is caused by paralysis of the smooth superior tarsal muscle. Furthermore, this patient's symptoms are fatigable and involve other muscle groups, which is not consistent with Horner syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Pupillary involvement is not a feature of myasthenia gravis, as the pupillary sphincter muscles are not affected. Fixed, dilated pupils (parasympathetic dysfunction) and symmetric weakness are more suggestive of botulism. However, botulism typically presents as an acute, descending paralysis and does not have the chronic, fluctuating course described by this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms demonstrate a classic pattern of fatigable weakness, which worsens with repeated muscle activity and improves with rest. The most likely diagnosis involves autoantibodies directed against components of the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blurred vision and difficulty keeping her eyes open. She also has occasional difficulty chewing, especially when eating meat or other foods that require prolonged chewing. The symptoms are worse at the end of the day. Physical examination shows bilateral drooping of the eyelids, which becomes more pronounced when she is asked to look upwards for 30 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Sustained blockade of actin myosin-binding sites
Decreased generation of end plate potential
Impaired flow of calcium ions between gap junctions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The inhibition of calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum facilitates muscle relaxation and is the mechanism of action of hydralazine. This patient, however, presents with myasthenia gravis (MG), which affects a different step in neuromuscular conduction and muscular contraction.

B) INCORRECT:

Interrupted transmission of T-tubule depolarization impairs the fast transmission of action potentials to muscle cells, which may reduce muscle strength. This pathology can be seen following myocardial infarction, for example. This patient, however, presents with symptoms of myasthenia gravis (MG), which affects a different step of neuromuscular conduction.

C) INCORRECT:

The blockade of myosin-binding sites on actin filaments is facilitated by tropomyosin. However, in a patient with myasthenia gravis (MG), another pathomechanism that sustains blockade of these binding sites is responsible for the symptoms of ptosis and muscle weakness.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with myasthenia gravis (MG), antibodies against post-synaptic ACh receptors compete with ACh at the post-synaptic membrane, which leads to decreased end plate potential despite normal ACh release. This causes muscle weakness and reduced endurance with repetitive muscle use, as manifested in this patient with difficulty chewing for a prolonged period of time and worsening of symptoms in the evening. Ptosis in myasthenia gravis can be provoked with the Simpson test, as seen here.
Image Description:

Blockade of ACh receptors (Left): ACh antibodies bind to postsynaptic ACh receptors and inhibit muscle activation.

Receptor internalization/degradation (middle): Binding of ACh antibody results in accelerated receptor degradation. The receptor is internalized and degraded by the muscle cell.

Complement activation (right): Binding of ACh autoantibodies results in complement activation and membrane attack complex formation, leading to the destruction of the neuromuscular junction and muscle cell lysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired flow of calcium ions between gap junctions would impair the coupled contraction of cardiac myocytes. Gap junctions are not present in the striated muscle that is affected by myasthenia gravis.
questions.hint: This patient's ptosis, muscle fatiguability, and positive Simpson test suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. Cholinesterase inhibitors can be used both to diagnose and treat myasthenia gravis.
